Yeh me too. There does seem to be a lot of highly specialised research 
in the field of biological neurons, but most of it is extremeley hard to 
digest or even understand where it fits in to the bigger picture. As one 
example take a look at the list of articles in the current edition of 
the journal of neuroscience:

http://www.jneurosci.org/current.shtml

One paper I came across elsewhere that has stood out so far is this one:

http://www.menem.com/~ilya/digital_library/neural/london-etal-02.pdf 
<http://www.menem.com/%7Eilya/digital_library/neural/london-etal-02.pdf>

Again, I don't fully understand everything that is being described in 
this paper but a few concepts emerged from skimming over it. The main 
concept is that individual neurons don't directly descibe a continous 
activation function such as a sigmoid, they actually fire in pulses, 
normally of fixed magnitude and that decay at varying rates. The 
frequency of the firing is roughly analagous to the ANN concept of an 
output signal. This isn't new to me but is an important point to keep in 
mind because some beneficial properties of bio-neurons may be 
attributable to nuances of this particular mechanism.  Also it seems 
that neurons usually act in large groups so that useful signals are 
actually an aggregrate output of many neurons - and I think this 
averaging out does actually give a sigmoid shape.

Bio-neurons also seem to exhibit varying delays between the activation 
level being reached and the neuron firing, and this may be useful in 
areas such as motion detection - where an array of neurons with a range 
of delays can be made to fire at the same time even though they each 
received an input signal at a different time, e.g. like when the image 
of a moving object passes over a visual sensor array.

With all of these nuances I think you have to try and decide whether 
they are just peculiarities of biology that are overcome by say, 
averaging outputs to describe a sigmoid, or whether they are inherently 
useful - note also that bio-neurons are prone to dying, so the averaging 
out helps out there too. Hopefully Koch's book will answer some of these 
questions.

Colin.
